Layout

Container/Jumbo

These elements provide desktop and mobile aware containers for your applications. These containers are useful for building static webpages that look good on phones, tablets and desktop devices.

 
<gs-container>...</gs-container>

<gs-jumbo>...</gs-jumbo>

<gs-jumbo>
<gs-container>...</gs-container>
</gs-jumbo>
Skeleton Container
Demo

A basic <gs-container> element with a header and paragraph. It will resize to the window and flow text.

 
<gs-container>...</gs-container>
Attribute "padded"
Demo

To add padding to a <gs-container> you just add the "padded" attribute.

 
<gs-container padded>...</gs-container>
Attribute "min-width"
Demo

The "min-width" attribute tells the <gs-container> to snap to particular width when the window reaches certain points. It takes a list of widths seperated by semi-colons. Precedence for the sizes is determined by order, so the last width is more important that the first. In this example the container will change it's width when the window is 300px or wider, 500px or wider and 700px or wider.

Note 1: Resize the window to see this behaviour.

Note 2: When the window snaps to a width (e.g. 500px) it might (depending on OS and OS settings) be a little thinner than 500px to make room in case there is a scrollbar next to the container.

Here are some shortcuts for pre-set widths:

  1. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  2. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  3. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

 
<gs-container min-width="200px;300px;500px;700px;lrg;">...</gs-container>
Attribute "media"
Demo

The "media" attribute tells the <gs-container> to snap to particular width based on CSS Media Queries.

The "media" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of these expressions is "<MEDIA-SELECTOR> {<WIDTH>};". Precedence for these expressions is determined by order, so the last expression is more important that the first.

Here are some shortcuts for pre-set widths:

  1. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  2. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  3. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

 
<gs-container media="all {small}; (min-width: medium) {medium}; print {600px};">...</gs-container>
Skeleton Jumbo Example
Demo

A basic <gs-jumbo> element with a header and paragraph. It will resize to the window and flow text. This element is for making content large. 

<gs-jumbo>...</gs-jumbo>
Jumbo with Container Min Width Example
Demo

A <gs-container> within a <gs-jumbo> with a header and paragraph. The Jumbo background will be full width, the gs-container will snap to certain widths. 

<gs-jumbo><gs-container min-width="sml;med;lrg">...</gs-container></gs-jumbo>

Dialog

These Javascript functions put a modal dialog in front of the document. The dialog has a transparent shadow behind it to cover the document.

 
GS.openDialog(<TEMPLATE-ID>[, <AFTER-OPEN-CALLBACK>[, <BEFORE-CLOSE-CALLBACK>]]);
GS.openDialogToElement(<elementTarget>, <TEMPLATE-ID>, <DIRECTION-REQUEST>[, <AFTER-OPEN-CALLBACK>[, <BEFORE-CLOSE-CALLBACK>]]);
GS.msgbox(<TITLE>, <MESSAGE>, <BUTTONS>, <CALLBACK>);
GS.inputbox(<TITLE>, <MESSAGE>, <CALLBACK>);
Skeleton Container
Demo

A basic dialog with some text and a button in it. To make the dialog aware of the close button you must put the "dialogclose" attribute on it. The dialog will have the following behaviors:

  1. A shadow will cover the document and the dialog will be in front of it.
  2. You can't click the page behind the dialog because of the shadow.
  3. You can dismiss the dialog by clicking the "Ok" button.
 
GS.openDialog('dialog-documentation');
gs-page
Demo

A dialog with a gs-page as its content. This is the most common way of putting content into a dialog. 

<template id="dialog-documentation">
    <gs-page>
        ...
    </gs-page>
</template>
After Open
Demo

In this example we have a dialog that can be opened by two different buttons. The first button will just open the dialog, the second button will open the dialog and change it after it opens. 

GS.openDialog('dialog-documentation', function () {...});
Attribute [data-overlay-close]
Demo

The [data-overlay-close] attribute allows the user to dismiss the dialog by clicking outside of the dialog. 

<template data-overlay-close>
    ...
</template>
Attribute [no-background]
Demo

The [no-background] attribute disables the modal background. 

<template no-background>
    ...
</template>
Before Close
Demo

In this example we have a dialog that has two close buttons. Once one of the buttons is clicked a function will run and that function will be sent the click event and the text of the element that was clicked. 

GS.openDialog('dialog-documentation', '', function (event, strAnswer) {
    // this function runs after a close element has been clicked
    //      but before the dialog is taken out of the DOM
    // strAnswer contains the text of the close element that was clicked
    if (strAnswer === 'Yes') {
        alert('You clicked "Yes".');
    } else {
        alert('You clicked "No".');
    }
});
Closing A Dialog From Javascript By Template ID
Demo

A dialog that is closed using a javascript function. 

GS.closeDialog('dialog-documentation', 'Ok');
Error Theme
Demo

A dialog with the "error" theme. The header and footer of this dialog will be red. The theme is specified by the "data-theme" attribute on the template element. Currently "data-theme" can only be set to "error" and "regular". 

<template data-theme="error">
    ...
</template>
Max Width/Height
Demo

A dialog with a custom max width and height set. The maximum width is specified by the "data-max-width" attribute on the template element and maximum height is specified by the "data-max-height" attribute. The defaults for these parameters is "700px". 

<template data-max-width="200px" data-max-height="200px">
    ...
</template>
Width and Height Mode
Demo

In this example we have six dialogs, each dialog has a different width/height setting. The default for this parameter is "detect".

  • Mode "detect": This mode attempts to give the best experience based on the content height.
  • Mode "phone": This mode goes to max_width and max_height until the page gets too small.
  • Mode "touch": This mode is full width and height on a touch device, defaults to "detect" everywhere else.
  • Mode "constrained": This mode is full width and height on a touch device, grow vertically with content everywhere else.
  • Mode "full": This mode is full width and height all of the time.
 
<template data-mode="detect">
    ...
</template>
GS.openDialogToElement
Demo

Opening a dialog from a <template> that is positioned to a target element. 

function testDialog() {
    GS.openDialogToElement(
        document.getElementById('target'), // element to position too
        'testTemplate', // template for the dialog
        'right', // side that the dialog should try to go to
                 //   if the dialog can't go on that side it
                 //   will try other sides
    function () {
        // after open, same as GS.openDialog
    }, function (event, strAnswer) {
        // before close, same as GS.openDialog
    });
}
Message Box
Demo

A dialog with a header and some text. 

GS.msgbox('Dialog Header', 'Dialog Content');
Input Box
Demo

A dialog with a header, some text, and an input. The third parameter is a callback function that has one argument, the text the user typed or empty string if the user canceled it. 

GS.inputbox('Dialog Header', 'Dialog Content', function (text) {
    alert('You typed:\n' + text);
});
Accessibility
Demo

In order to be accessible, dialogs should close when escape is pressed, to do this add key="escape" no-modifier-key to the [dialogclose] button that has no effect. 

<gs-button dialogclose key="escape" no-modifier-key>Cancel</gs-button>

Font Size

The font tag allows you to change the font size of text based on window size or media query.

 
<gs-font></gs-font>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-font element. This font element will have the following behaviors:

  1. When the window is above 0 width the font-size will be set to 10px
  2. When the window is above or equal to 500px width the font-size will be set to 20px
 
<gs-font min-width="all {10px}; 500px {20px};">
    ...
</gs-font>
Attribute [min-width]
Demo

This "min-width" attribute enables you to change the font size depending the minimum width of the screen. The "min-width" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of an expression is "<WINDOW-WIDTH> {<FONT-SIZE>};". Precedence for the font-sizes is determined by order, so the last expression is more important that the first.

There are several shortcuts for some pre-set sizes:

  1. All instances of "all" are replaced with "0px"
  2. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  3. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  4. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

In this example the gs-font element will change the font-size at 4 widths. 

<gs-font min-width="all {2em}; 300px {3em}; 600px {4em}; 900px {5em};">
    ...
</gs-font>
Attribute [media]
Demo

The "media" attribute enables you to change the font size depending CSS Media Queries. The "media" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of an expression is "<MEDIA-SELECTOR> {<FONT-SIZE>};". Precedence for the font-sizes is determined by order, so the last expression is more important that the first.

There are several shortcuts for some pre-set sizes:

  1. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  2. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  3. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

In this example the gs-font element will change the font-size at 4 media conditions. 

<gs-font media="all {10px}; screen and (min-width: 500px) {15px}; screen and (min-width: small) {20px}; print {25px};">
    ...
</gs-font>

Grid

The gs-grid element is used to contain a set of gs-block elements for displaying tabular data. The gs-block elements are similar to cells in Excel and similar to <td> elements in HTML tables.

The gs-grid element is used for setting the width of the gs-block columns. A grid with more blocks than columns will be broken into rows of blocks. When the page gets too thin the grid can make all of it's blocks 're-flow' to display one block per line.

When would you use a grid instead of a table?

    Generally, if you are displaying data, you want <table>. A table element attempts to resize it's columns to show each cell's content. It can also be configured to re-flow using CSS such that labels are repeated for each row. This way each field is identified in the current viewport. You need this when displaying tabular data. For example, ten columns of dates are useless if you don't have a label telling you which date is which.

    If you are not displaying tabular data, then you may want a gs-grid. A gs-grid gives you control of your column widths. In the case of layout, you typically want to set your column widths and have them be respected so your layout looks correct. For example, a grid of buttons is a common use for gs-grid. If you set a gs-grid of buttons to re-flow on a narrow screen, they do not need additional labels. They'll look and work properly whether it re-flows or not. 

<gs-grid>
    <gs-block>...</gs-block>
    <gs-block>...</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-grid element with three blocks. Without attributes the grid will have the following behaviors:

  1. All three blocks will be equal width.
  2. All three blocks will flow onto their own lines when the viewport is below a certain width.
 
<gs-grid>
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Attribute [gutter]
Demo

A gs-grid element with the "gutter" attribute set and contains three blocks. This grid will have space between the content of the blocks. 

<gs-grid gutter>
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Attribute [padded]
Demo

The padded attribute on a gs-grid adds padding to the gs-grid. The width of the grid is not affected by this padding. 

<gs-grid padded>
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Attribute [widths]
Demo

A gs-grid element with the "widths" attribute will set the widths of its columns. When setting the column widths, the gs-grid will total all the column values and divide each column by the total to get a percentage. In this example, the first column will be set to 20%, the second to 30% and the third to 50%. 

<gs-grid widths="2,3,5">
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Attribute [reflow-at]
Demo

In this example we have three gs-grid elements with the "reflow-at" attribute set. The value of the "reflow-at" attribute will determine at what window width the gs-grid element will put it's blocks in one vertical column.

Here is a list of shortcuts for some pre-set widths:

  1. "small" or "sml" is replaced with "992px"
  2. "medium" or "med" are replaced with "1200px"
  3. "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "10000px"
 
<gs-grid reflow-at="400px">
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Multiple Rows
Demo

A gs-grid element with the "widths" attribute set for three blocks but it contains six blocks. The widths set in the "widths" attribute will be applied to the first three blocks and will be repeated on the second three blocks. 

<gs-grid widths="1,2,3">
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 4</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 5</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 6</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Setting a Block [width] Attribute
Demo

A gs-grid element will use the "widths" attribute to set width attributes only on blocks that do not contain width attributes already. In this example, the fourth and fifth blocks have their "width" attributes pre-set. 

<gs-grid widths="1,2,3">
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-warning width="2">Block 4</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger width="4" bg-primary>Block 5</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 6</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 7</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 8</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Attribute [min-width]
Demo

This "min-width" attribute enables you to change the block numbering and reflowing depending the minimum width of the screen. The "min-width" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of an expression is "<WINDOW-WIDTH> {<BLOCKS>};". The BLOCKS portion of the expression is either "reflow" or a comma-seperated list of widths (e.g. "1,1,2"). Each WINDOW-WIDTH must be larger than the one before it.

Here is a list of shortcuts for some pre-set sizes:

  1. All instances of "all" are replaced with "0px"
  2. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  3. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  4. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

In this example the gs-grid element will change it's blocks at 3 widths. 

<gs-grid min-width="all {reflow}; 400px {1,1}; sml {1,1,1};">
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 4</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-primary>Block 5</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 6</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Attribute [media]
Demo

The "media" attribute enables you to change the block numbering and reflowing depending CSS Media Queries. The BLOCKS portion of the expression is either "reflow" or a comma-seperated list of widths (e.g. "1,1,2"). The "media" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of an expression is "<MEDIA-SELECTOR> {<BLOCKS>};". Precedence for the font-sizes is determined by order, so the last expression is more important that the first.

There are several shortcuts for some pre-set sizes:

  1. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  2. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  3. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

In this example the gs-grid element will change it's blocks at 3 media conditions. 

<gs-grid media="(max-width: 400px) {1,1}; (min-width: 401px) {1,1,1}; print {reflow};">
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 1</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 2</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-success>Block 3</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-danger>Block 4</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-primary>Block 5</gs-block>
    <gs-block bg-warning>Block 6</gs-block>
</gs-grid>
Button
Demo

A gs-grid element with four blocks. Each contains a button with some or all of its corner rounding removed. In this example, gs-grid causes these buttons to look like a group. 

<gs-grid>
    <gs-block>
        <gs-button icon="backward" remove-right icontop></gs-button>
    </gs-block>
    <gs-block>
        <gs-button icon="pause" remove-all icontop></gs-button>
    </gs-block>
    <gs-block>
        <gs-button icon="forward" remove-all icontop></gs-button>
    </gs-block>
    <gs-block>
        <gs-button icon="volume-up" remove-left icontop></gs-button>
    </gs-block>
</gs-grid>

Group

The gs-group element is used to contain and label a set of related elements.

 
<gs-group name="..."></gs-group>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-group element. The "name" attribute is required and it determines the text for the label below the box. 

<gs-group name="Buttons">
    <gs-button bg-warning inline>Button 1</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-danger inline>Button 2</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-success inline>Button 3</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-info inline>Button 4</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-primary inline>Button 5</gs-button>
    <gs-button inline>Button 6</gs-button>
    <gs-button inline>Button 7</gs-button>
</gs-group>
[padded] Attribute
Demo

To put some space around a gs-group element you use the "padded" attribute. 

<gs-group name="Buttons" padded>
    <gs-button bg-warning inline>Button 1</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-danger inline>Button 2</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-success inline>Button 3</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-info inline>Button 4</gs-button>
    <gs-button bg-primary inline>Button 5</gs-button>
    <gs-button inline>Button 6</gs-button>
    <gs-button inline>Button 7</gs-button>
</gs-group>

Image

The gs-img element is for adding an image to your page and having it change it's size depending on window width or CSS Media Queries.

 
<gs-img src="..."></gs-img>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-img element. This element will have the following behaviors:

  1. The gs-img will center itself
  2. The gs-img will always be 272px wide by 478px tall
 
<gs-img src="doc-library/Lock.png" min-width="all {272px, 478px};"></gs-img>
Attribute [min-width]
Demo

The "min-width" attribute enables you to change the images size depending the minimum width of the screen. The "min-width" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of an expression is "<WINDOW-WIDTH> {<IMAGE-WIDTH>, <IMAGE-HEIGHT>};". If no image height is specified: the gs-img will use the image width as the image height. Precedence for the expressions is determined by order, so the last expression is more important that the first.

Here is a list of shortcuts for some pre-set sizes:

  1. All instances of "all" are replaced with "0px"
  2. All instances of "small" or "sml" are replaced with "768px"
  3. All instances of "medium" or "med" are replaced with "992px"
  4. All instances of "large" or "lrg" are replaced with "1200px"

In this example the gs-font element will change the image size at 4 widths. 

<gs-img src="doc-library/Lock.png" min-width="all {100px}; 600px {200px}; sml {300px}; med {500px};"></gs-img>
Attribute [media]
Demo

The "media" attribute enables you to change the image size depending CSS Media Queries. The "media" attribute takes a list of expressions seperated by semi-colons. The format of an expression is "<MEDIA-SELECTOR> {<IMAGE-WIDTH>, <IMAGE-HEIGHT>};". Precedence for the expressions is determined by order, so the last expression is more important that the first.

There are several shortcuts for some pre-set sizes:

  1. All instances of "small" or [sml] are replaced with "768px"
  2. All instances of "medium" or [med] are replaced with "992px"
  3. All instances of "large" or [lrg] are replaced with "1200px"

In this example the gs-font element will change the font-size at 4 media conditions. 

<gs-img src="doc-library/Lock.png" media="all {100px}; screen and (min-width: 500px) {150px, 200px}; screen and (min-width: small) {200px}; print {250px};"></gs-img>
Attribute [image-cover]
Demo

The "image-cover" attribute enables you to fill the gs-img even if some of the image will get chopped off. 

<gs-img src="doc-library/Lock.png" min-width="all {320px, 478px};" image-cover></gs-img>
Attribute [align]
Demo

The "align" attribute enables you to make the image go to the left or right instead of center. 

<gs-img src="doc-library/Lock.png" min-width="all {100px};" align="left"></gs-img>

Page

These elements provide desktop and mobile aware containers for your applications. Headers and footers are fixed at the top and bottom of the viewport and expand to display whatever you put in them. The gs-body contains your main content and becomes scrollable when appropriate.

 
<gs-page>
        <gs-header>...</gs-header>
        <gs-body>...</gs-body>
        <gs-footer>...</gs-footer>
</gs-page>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-page element with a gs-body. The page will expand to 100% width and height and if the content is still too long to be displayed, the gs-body will get a scrollbar. 

<gs-page>
    <gs-body>
        ...
    </gs-body>
</gs-page>
Header
Demo

A gs-page element with a gs-body and a gs-header.

Note the header will be fixed to the top of the gs-page and if the body content is too long it will get a scrollbar. 

<gs-page>
    <gs-header>
        ...
    </gs-header>
    <gs-body>
        ...
    </gs-body>
</gs-page>
Footer
Demo

A gs-page element with a gs-body and a gs-footer. The footer will be fixed to the bottom of the gs-page and if the body content is too long it will get a scrollbar. 

<gs-page>
    <gs-body>
        ...
    </gs-body>
    <gs-footer>
        ...
    </gs-footer>
</gs-page>
Header And Footer
Demo

gs-page element with a gs-body, gs-header and a gs-footer. The header and footer will be fixed to the top and bottom respectively and if the content is too long the gs-body will get a scrollbar. 

<gs-page>
    <gs-header>
        ...
    </gs-header>
    <gs-body>
        ...
    </gs-body>
    <gs-footer>
        ...
    </gs-footer>
</gs-page>
Header And Envelope
Demo

A gs-page element with a gs-body (containing a gs-envelope) and a gs-header.

        </gs-envelope>
    </gs-body>
</gs-page>
Header And Footer Button
Demo

A gs-page element with a gs-body, gs-header and a gs-footer. In this example the header and footer each have a grid of buttons inside them. 

<gs-page>
    <gs-header>
        <gs-grid>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="refresh"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="pencil"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="adjust"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="trash-o"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
        </gs-grid>
    </gs-header>
    ...
</gs-page>
Header And Footer Button
Demo

A gs-page element with a gs-body, gs-header and a gs-footer. In this example the header and footer each have a grid of buttons inside them. 

<gs-page>
    <gs-header>
        <gs-grid>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="refresh"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="pencil"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="adjust"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
            <gs-block>
                <center><gs-button icononly jumbo icon="trash-o"></gs-button></center>
            </gs-block>
        </gs-grid>
    </gs-header>
    ...
</gs-page>

Panel

Panels go by various names. Left-menu, side-menu, side-bar, etc... This element is used for creating side panels that work predictably across all screen sizes. Typical side panel behavior is accessable via attributes and methods. Sometimes panel functionality needs to be included in browser history (to enable the back button). To make it easy to include panel functionality in browser history this element is query string aware.

 
<gs-panel>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-panel element with a left bar. Without attributes, when the viewport is small enough to cause the panel to overlap the content, the default behavior is for a shadow to fall over the content. When this happens the panel is dismissable. If there is enough room to display both panel and content then the panel is not dismissable. When using no attributes make sure you don't end up with a button that is supposed to dismiss the panel when that functionality is not available. 

<gs-panel id="panel">
    <gs-page id="left-bar" style="width: 17em;">
        <gs-header>
            <center><h3>Panel</h3></center>
        </gs-header>
        <gs-body>
            <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('panel').hide('left-bar');">Close Panel</gs-button>
        </gs-body>
    </gs-page>
    <gs-page>
        <gs-header>
            <center><h3>Page</h3></center>
        </gs-header>
        <gs-body>
            <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('panel').show('left-bar');">Open Panel</gs-button>
        </gs-body>
    </gs-page>
</gs-panel>
Right Panel
Demo

To make a right-panel, simply put the style="width:" on the last gs-page element in the gs-panel element. 

<gs-panel id="panel">
    <gs-page>
        <gs-header>
            <center><h3>Page</h3></center>
        </gs-header>
        <gs-body>
            <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('panel').show('right-bar');">Open Panel</gs-button>
        </gs-body>
    </gs-page>
    <gs-page id="right-bar" style="width: 17em;">
        <gs-header>
            <center><h3>Panel</h3></center>
        </gs-header>
        <gs-body>
            <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('panel').hide('right-bar');">Close Panel</gs-button>
        </gs-body>
    </gs-page>
</gs-panel>
Attribute [no-shadow-dismiss]
Demo

When the viewport is small enough to cause the panel to overlap the content, a shadow will fall over the content. The default behavior of gs-panel is to allow a user to dismiss the panel by clicking on the shadow. To prevent "click on shadow to dismiss" behavior, add the no-shadow-dismiss attribute to the gs-panel tag. 

<gs-panel id="panel" no-shadow-dismiss>
    ...
</gs-panel>
Attribute [dismissible]
Demo

When the viewport is wide enough to display a panel and content side by side without overlap, the default behavior is to prevent the panel from being closed. In this example, we wish to dismiss the panel even when there is plenty of room. By adding the dismissible attribute, the panel becomes dismissable regardless of viewport size. 

<gs-panel id="panel" dismissible>
    ...
</gs-panel>
Method .hide()
Demo

To hide the panel, gs-panel provides the "hide" method. In this example we run the hide method on the panel and give it the id "left-bar" as an argument. 

document.getElementById('<id of panel>').hide('<id of page>');
Method .show()
Demo

To show the panel, gs-panel provides the "show" method. In this example we run the show method on the panel and give it the id "left-bar" as an argument. 

document.getElementById('<id of panel>').show('<id of page>');
Method .toggle()
Demo

To show the panel, gs-panel provides the "toggle" method. In this example we run the toggle method on the panel and give it the id "left-bar" as an argument. 

document.getElementById('<id of panel>').toggle('<id of page>');

Push Message

This Javascript function puts a temporary message with HTML in it at the top of the document.

 
GS.pushMessage(<HTML>[, <TIME>[, <CALLBACK>]]);
Skeleton
Demo

A basic pushmessage with some text in it. The message will have the following behaviors:

  1. The first one will appear at the top of the screen. Subsequent messages will appear at the bottom of the list of messages.
  2. The messages will be permanent because we are not closing them.
 
GS.pushMessage('This is a pushmessage.');
Timed Closing
Demo

A pushmessage with some text in it and a time. These messages will close themselves after 1.5 seconds. 

GS.pushMessage('This is a test message that will close itself.', 1500);
Manual Closing
Demo

A button to open a pushmessage and a button to close a pushmessage. 

// close message at index 0 in the message array
GS.closePushMessage(arrMessage[0]);

// remove message from array
arrMessage.splice(0, 1);
Dynamic Message
Demo

A pushmessage with some text in it, a time and a callback function. These messages will have a number that increments inside. 

var i = 1;

function message() {
    GS.pushMessage('This is message #<span class="count"></span>.', 1000, function () {
        // here "this" is the element the HTML is inside.
        // we are getting the ".count" span
        //      so that we can put "i" into it.
        this.querySelector('.count').textContent = i;
        i += 1;
    });
}

Scroller

The gs-scroller element is for navigating around content by clicking and dragging to move and using the scroll wheel to zoom in and out.

Notes:
  • On a phone this element is only scrollable, not zoomable.
  • The gs-scroller element must have it's contents inside a gs-scroller-inner element.
  • The gs-scroller element changes it's zoom by adjusting font-size, so make sure your content responds to font-size (including any width/height on the gs-scroller-inner).
 
<gs-scroller>
    <gs-scroller-inner style="width {WIDTH}; height: {HEIGHT};">
        ...
    </gs-scroller-inner>
</gs-scroller>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-scroller element. 

<gs-scroller>
    <gs-scroller-inner style="width: 100em;">
        ...
    </gs-scroller-inner>
</gs-scroller>

Sticky Header/Footer

The gs-sticky element is for headers or footers that want to be stuck to the top or bottom of the screen only when they are scrolled past. Note 1: the gs-sticky element must have it's contents in a gs-sticky-inner. Note 2: in these examples the gs-sticky-inner elements have the "bg-primary" attribute on them just to make them easier to see.

 
<gs-sticky>
    <gs-sticky-inner>
        ...
    </gs-sticky-inner>
</gs-sticky>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-sticky element. Without attributes the gs-sticky will have the following behaviors:

  1. On a non-touch device: when the window is scrolled down below the point where the element naturally wants to be, it will stick to the top of the window
 
<gs-sticky>
    <gs-sticky-inner bg-primary>
        <center>...</center>
    </gs-sticky-inner>
</gs-sticky>
Attribute [direction]
Demo

The [direction] attribute allows you to make the contents of the gs-sticky element stick to the bottom. This is done by setting the [direction] attribute to "down". Note: scroll all the way down to see the code and scroll all the way down to see the footer's behaviour. 

<gs-sticky direction="down">
    <gs-sticky-inner bg-primary>
        <center>...</center>
    </gs-sticky-inner>
</gs-sticky>
Attribute [stuck]
Demo

The [stuck] attribute allows you to make the contents of the gs-sticky element always stick to the top or bottom depending on your choice. This is done by adding the [stuck] attribute. 

<gs-sticky stuck>
    <gs-sticky-inner bg-primary>
        <center>...</center>
    </gs-sticky-inner>
</gs-sticky>
Attribute [touch-device-allowed]
Demo

The [touch-device-allowed] attribute makes it so that the contents of the gs-sticky element stick on touch devices as well as non-touch devices. This is done by adding the [touch-device-allowed] attribute. 

<gs-sticky touch-device-allowed>
    <gs-sticky-inner bg-primary>
        <center>...</center>
    </gs-sticky-inner>
</gs-sticky>

Switch

The gs-switch element is a content switcher, similar to a tab control without the tab names. In fact, if you need a tab view, using a gs-switch element is a great way to build one.

The gs-switch element uses standard HTML5 <template> elements for storing content. A template element is a tag that allows you to store html in an HTML document that a browser will not render. Its purpose is to store the html in a way that doesn't require escaping. This keeps the HTML clean and readable.

Using the gs-switch is simple. On each template, set a unique "for" attribute, then on the gs-switch element, set the "value" attribute to the template you want displayed.

By default, the initial template will be displayed on load. You can set the initial template for a switch by setting the "value" attribute in your HTML document, then at any time you can switch the template that is displayed by setting the "value" attribute through javascript. 

<gs-switch>
    <template for="{template_name}">
        ...
    </template>
    <template for="{template_name}">
        ...
    </template>
</gs-switch>
Skeleton
Demo

In this example we have a gs-switch element with 2 templates. The switch shows template-1 on load because it is the first template. After load, the content can be switched by setting the value of the switch. Click the button to switch to "template-2".

All gs-switch elements default to one hundred percent width and height. 

<gs-switch id="switch">
    <template for="template-1">
        <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-2';">Go to template 2</gs-button>
        ...
    </template>
    <template for="template-2">
        <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-1';">Go to template 1</gs-button>
        ...
    </template>
</gs-switch>
Page
Demo

A gs-switch element with two templates that contain gs-page elements. Again, we default to template-1 because it is the first template. The content is switched by setting the value of the switch from the buttons.

Notice how the page within the switch covers the switch. This is normal behavior for gs-page. 

<gs-switch id="switch">
    <template for="template-1">
        <gs-page>
            <gs-header><h3>Page 1 Header</h3></gs-header>
            <gs-body padded>
                <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-2';">Go to page 2</gs-button>
            </gs-body>
            <gs-footer><h3>Page 1 Footer</h3></gs-footer>
        </gs-page>
    </template>
    <template for="template-2">
        <gs-page>
            <gs-header><h3>Page 2 Header</h3></gs-header>
            <gs-body padded>
                <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-1';">Go to page 1</gs-button>
            </gs-body>
            <gs-footer><h3>Page 2 Footer</h3></gs-footer>
        </gs-page>
    </template>
</gs-switch>
Page
Demo

A gs-switch element with two templates that contain gs-page elements. Again, we default to template-1 because it is the first template. The content is switched by setting the value of the switch from the buttons.

Notice how the page within the switch covers the switch. This is normal behavior for gs-page. 

<gs-switch id="switch">
    <template for="template-1">
        <gs-page>
            <gs-header><h3>Page 1 Header</h3></gs-header>
            <gs-body padded>
                <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-2';">Go to page 2</gs-button>
            </gs-body>
            <gs-footer><h3>Page 1 Footer</h3></gs-footer>
        </gs-page>
    </template>
    <template for="template-2">
        <gs-page>
            <gs-header><h3>Page 2 Header</h3></gs-header>
            <gs-body padded>
                <gs-button onclick="document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-1';">Go to page 1</gs-button>
            </gs-body>
            <gs-footer><h3>Page 2 Footer</h3></gs-footer>
        </gs-page>
    </template>
</gs-switch>
Preset Value
Demo

In this example the gs-switch element has the "template" attribute set to "template-2" in the HTML document. As a result, template-2 is shown on load. 

<gs-switch id="switch" template="template-2">
    <template for="template-1">
        ...
    </template>
    <template for="template-2">
        ...
    </template>
</gs-switch>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will cause the switch element to refresh whenever that particulary key is changed in the querystring.
 
<gs-switch qs="test1">
    <template for="template-1">
        ...
    </template>
    <template for="template-2">
        ...
    </template>
</gs-switch>
DoT.js Javascript Variable
Demo

In this example we are going to use Dot.js to allow for more complex behavior.

The DoT.js templating engine accepts string content and parses it to find curly braced content "{{! example }}". It then executes anything found within braces as javascript code. For more information, see the Dot.js documentation.

In the example, the gs-switch element has a Dot.js expression in the template attribute. The expression asks Dot.js to substitue the value of the javascript variable "strTemplateVariable" for the template attribute. In other words, Dot.js converts template="{{! strTemplateVariable }}" to template="template-1".

This conversion occurs on load automatically. You can also trigger a gs-switch to refresh using the refresh method or by setting the template attribute. See the next two examples for details. 

<gs-switch template="{{! strTemplateVariable }}">
    ...
</gs-switch>
Trigger A GS-Switch To Refresh
Demo

To get a gs-switch to refresh you can call refresh() on it.

In this example, template-1 is the initial template because the strTemplateVariable is set to "template-1". Click the "Set strTemplateVariable to template-2" button to change the value of strTemplateVariable to "template-2". Notice at this point the gs-switch has not changed, it's still showing template-1. Now click the "Refresh" button. The refresh method is called on the gs-switch and template-2 is displayed. 

document.getElementById('switch').refresh();
Trigger A GS-Switch By Setting The [template] Attribute
Demo

To get a gs-switch to switch immediately you can set the [template] attribute with javascript. The gs-switch will sense the change and refresh immediately.

In this example, template-1 is the initial template because no value was set in the HTML document. Click the buttons to set the [template] attribute. Note that Javascript provides two ways to do this. 

document.getElementById('switch').setAttribute('template','template-2');
document.getElementById('switch').template = 'template-1';
DoT.js And Query String
Demo

This example demonstrates a way to get behavior like you get with the "qs" attribute, but enhanced with the ability to set the template with an expression.

Our initial query string is set to "template=template-2". Also notice the gs-switch value attribute is set to "{{! qs.template }}".

When our page loads, Dot.js will parse the query string variable "qs", find the value for key "template" and then insert "template-2" into the gs-switch template attribute in place of the braced expression "! qs.template". Next, the gs-switch will initialize and set template-2 as the visible template.

Notice that if you change the query string below, the template will change but this is only a demonstration of initial page load functionality. We trigger a page reload whenever you type to make the example easy to test. Look to the next two examples to see how enhance this example to change dynamically with the query string. 

<gs-switch template="{{! 'template-' + qs.template }}">
    <template for="template-1">
        This is template-{{! qs.template }}.
    </template>
</gs-switch>
Attribute [refresh-on-querystring-change]
Demo

To make the gs-switch refresh when the query string is updated, you add the gs-switch attribute [refresh-on-querystring-change].

Note that within the templates we're referencing the qs.template variable and its being filled in as the template loads. 

<gs-switch template="{{! 'template-' + qs.template }}" refresh-on-querystring-change>
    ...
</gs-switch>
Attribute [refresh-on-querystring-values]
Demo

Sometimes you don't want the gs-switch to reload for every change of the query string. You may be changing query string values unrelated to the gs-switch and you don't want to experience a delay for a large gs-switch to refresh.

To make the gs-switch refresh only when the query string key "template" changes value, you add the gs-switch attribute [refresh-on-querystring-values] with the value "template".

If you want to refresh on changes to a list of columns you can put a comma seperated list of columns in the refresh-on-querystring-values attribute. That could look something like refresh-on-querystring-values="template, page".

Note that within the templates we're referencing the qs.template variable and its being filled in as the template loads. 

<gs-switch template="{{! qs.template }}" refresh-on-querystring-values="template">
    ...
</gs-switch>
Refreshing A GS-Switch Without Running DoT.js
Demo

Sometimes you don't want the gs-switch to run a template's content through DoT.js. It may be large, or it may just not need it. You can prevent DoT.js from being run on template content by using the static attribute.

Note that DoT.js will always be run on the gs-switch's attributes and the template's attributes. The static attribute only prevents DoT.js from parsing the template content.

In this example we've placed the static attribute on template-2 and you can see it didn't resolve the qs.template expression. If you move it to the gs-switch it will prevent DoT.js from parsing both templates. 

<gs-switch template="{{! qs.template }}" refresh-on-querystring-values="template">
    <template for="template-1" static>
        This won't template: {{! qs.template }}
    </template>
</gs-switch>

  • The [txt-muted] attribute makes the text gray.

  • The [txt-danger] attribute makes the text red.

  • The [bg-success] attribute makes the background green.
  • The [bg-info] attribute makes the background light blue.
  • The [bg-warning] attribute makes the background yellow.
  • The [bg-danger] attribute makes the background red.

The rows attribute sets the height of the gs-ace in rows. 

<gs-ace rows="10"></gs-ace>
Attribute [onchange=""]
Demo

To run javascript when the value changes, use the [onchange=""] attribute. 

<gs-ace onchange="alert('value changed')"></gs-ace>
Attribute [value=""]
Demo

To set the default value for the <gs-ace>, use the [value=""] attribute. 

<gs-ace value="testing"></gs-ace>
Attribute [encrypted="keyVariable"]
Demo

When you have a database column that contains sensitive information use the [encrypted] attribute to encrypt the value. The column will be encrypted with AES using the global variable that matches the [encrypted] attribute. If the gs-ace detects a bad password, it will emit a password-error event with the key variable in event.keyVariable and either 'bad' or 'no' in event.reason. The password for this example is 'test'. 

<gs-ace encrypted="crypto_password" value="U2FsdGVkX1/PaAZ+V5adE6YTU9oCM6YPl5GN2TTaM20="></gs-ace>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-ace qs="test1" placeholder="test1" rows="2"></gs-ace>
<gs-ace qs="test2=value" placeholder="test2" rows="2"></gs-ace>
<gs-ace qs="test3=hidden" placeholder="test3" rows="2"></gs-ace>
<gs-ace qs="test4!=hidden" placeholder="test4" rows="2"></gs-ace>
Attribute [autoresize]
Demo

Rather then automatically resizing the <gs-ace> to take up 100% space, it can automatically resize itself when you use the [autoresize] attribute to the text length. 

<gs-ace autoresize></gs-ace>
Attribute [disabled]
Demo

With the [disabled] attribute, you can control whether or not you can use the control. 

<gs-ace disabled></gs-ace>
Attribute [readonly]
Demo

The [readonly] attribute is similar to [disabled] because it prevents the value from changing. The only difference is that [readonly] does not grey out the field and [disabled] does. 

<gs-ace readonly></gs-ace>

Buttons And Toggle

It is recommended that you use buttons in place of hyperlinks when the target is an application or download. This way your users will come to expect that buttons 'do things' while hyperlinks lead to a document which will display in the browser. Your users will appreciate consistent application of button and hyperlink usage.

Buttons come with button-appropriate styling such as hover which can be altered using the greyspots css file.

Buttons provide the [onclick] attribute for inline Javascript. Alternately, you can of course use addEventListener('click', function(){}) instead. Additionally, there are href and target attributes like HTML anchor tags.

See below for examples of the many options available for button behavior and styling. Note that the special-use buttons covered in the last section can also use all of the behavior and styling options. 

<gs-button></gs-button>
<gs-email-button></gs-email-button>
<gs-facetime-button></gs-facetime-button>
<gs-map-button></gs-map-button>
<gs-phone-button></gs-phone-button>
<gs-skype-button></gs-skype-button>
<gs-tracking-button></gs-tracking-button>
<gs-toggle></gs-toggle>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic gs-button element. Without attributes the button will have the following behavior:

  1. When the button receives mousedown, the appearance chages. It will change back after mouseup or mouseout.
 
<gs-button>...</gs-button>
Attribute [onclick]
Demo

The onclick attribute allows you to run Javascript as a result of clicking on the button. 

<gs-button onclick="alert('test')">...</gs-button>
Event [click]
Demo

Another way of running Javascript from a button is to add a listener to the button. Typically you use a [id] attribute to make sure you are listening on the right button. 

document.getElementById('button_test').addEventListener('click', function () {
    ...
});
Attributes [href] and [value]
Demo

Sometimes you want to open a page like you would a link, but you want the appearance of a button. The [target] and [href] attributes work just like with an <a> tag. This is especially recommended if the target is an application or a download. Note that new windows will either appear as new browser windows or new tabs depending on brower settings. To force a file to download, use the HTML5 download="" attribute to set the file name. Or just use download by itself. Also note that the [href] and [value] attributes are interchangable. 

<gs-button href="http://www.wikipedia.org/" target="_blank">...</gs-button>
Attribute [qs=""]

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-button qs="test1">...</gs-button>
Icons
Demo

Buttons can have icons. These icons can be rotated and moved to different sides inside the button. 

<gs-button iconrotateright icononly icon="glass">...</gs-button>
Attribute [jumbo]
Demo

Buttons by default are control height, this is so that when you place a button next to a control it doesn't look out of place. When the "jumbo" attribute is present the button is larger than control height. 

<gs-button jumbo>...</gs-button>

Demo

When the [no-focus] attribute is present the button cannot be tabbed to. 

<gs-button no-focus>...</gs-button>

<gs-button key="a">...</gs-button>

Demo

In this example we have two buttons with the [key] and [no-modifier-key] attributes set. The [no-modifier-key] attribute means that you can't use CMD or CTRL to activate the hot-key. Note: you have to click into the example for it to work.

With this attribute, you can control what order your controls are tabbed to. 

<gs-button tabindex="1">...</gs-button>

Demo

The inline attribute forces the button to be the smallest size possible with the text. The mini attribute lessens the height of the button and removes the border. 

<gs-button mini inline>...</gs-button>
Attribute [disabled]
Demo

The disabled attribute greys out the button and prevents click events. 

<gs-button disabled>...</gs-button>
Attributes [bg-*] and [txt-*]
Demo

The bg- attributes makes the button stand out by changing the background color. The txt- attributes change the font color. 

<gs-button bg-primary>Primary</gs-button>
<gs-button bg-success>Success</gs-button>
<gs-button bg-info>Info</gs-button>

Special-use Button Examples

These button elements can't accept [href] and [target] attributes. All other attributes work as expected.
Email Button
Demo

This button will attempt to open a new email in an email client using the HREF="mailto:" attribute of the anchor tag. If the user does not have an email client configured then the behavior is determined by the browser and Operating System. Its possible not all "mailto:" keys (such as BCC) will populate properly for all clients so you should test on your user's system before relying on gs-email.

The gs-email-button is very useful but be aware that in some situations its best to put up a form and send email through the server. For example, on a public website its best to provide a form so that email addresses are not searchable by spammers. On the other hand, if you're writing a private application the user may want all outgoing email to be stored in their sent folder and the only way to do that is to use the "mailto:" API. 

<gs-email-button value="an-address@a-domain.com?subject=Feedback&body=Love It!&cc=a-diff-address@a-domain.com&bcc=another-diff-address@a-domain.com">...</gs-email-button>
Apple Facetime Button
Demo

This button will attempt open an Apple Facetime call. This button uses the "facetime:" link to attempt the call. 

<gs-facetime-button value="an-address@a-domain.com">...</gs-facetime-button>
Map Button
Demo

This button will open up a map in either Google Maps or Microsoft Bing Maps.

  • For Google Maps the button uses this link:
      https://maps.google.com/maps?q=LOCATIONTOSEARCHFOR

  • For Microsoft Bing Maps the button uses this link:
      http://www.bing.com/maps/default.aspx?q=LOCATIONTOSEARCHFOR

 
<gs-map-button google value="North Richland Hills">Primary</gs-map-button>
<gs-map-button bing value="North Richland Hills">...</gs-map-button>
Phone Button
Demo

This button will make a phone call if a phone line is available. Depending on the browser and operating system: if a phone line is not availible then it may send the link to applications such as Microsoft Skype. This button uses the tel: link to attempt the call. 

<gs-phone-button value="555-555-5555">...</gs-phone-button>
Microsoft Skype Button
Demo

This button will attempt to start a Microsoft Skype call. Microsoft Skype software must be installed for it to work. This button uses the "skype:" link to attempt the call. 

<gs-skype-button value="this.is.a.skype.name.that.i.just.made.up">...</gs-skype-button>
Package Tracking Button
Demo

This button will open package tracking pages for some common delivery services.

  • For UPS the button uses this link:
      http://www.ups.com/WebTracking/processInputRequest?tracknum=TRACKINGNUMBER

  • For USPS the button uses this link:
      https://tools.usps.com/go/TrackConfirmAction?tLabels=TRACKINGNUMBER

  • For FEDEX the button uses this link:
      https://www.fedex.com/apps/fedextrack/index.html?tracknumbers=TRACKINGNUMBER

 
<gs-tracking-button ups value="TRACKINGNUMBER">...</gs-tracking-button>
<gs-tracking-button usps value="TRACKINGNUMBER">...</gs-tracking-button>
<gs-tracking-button fedex value="TRACKINGNUMBER">...</gs-tracking-button>

Demo

<gs-toggle>...</gs-toggle>

To run javascript when the value changes, use the [onchange=""] attribute. 

<gs-toggle onchange="alert(this.value);">...</gs-toggle>

Dialog Button

This element is used to open a dialog at the click of a button, it accepts all of the same attributes of the normal <gs-button> except for [target]. 

<gs-dialog-button template="..."></gs-dialog-button>
Inner Template
Demo

This is an example of a <gs-dialog-button> that creates a dialog using an inner template. The template element must be an immediate child of the button for this to work. This is useful for a quick and simple dialog. 

<gs-dialog-button>
    <template>
        <h5>Example Dialog</h5>
        <gs-button dialogclose>Done</gs-button>
    </template>
    Example Dialog
</gs-dialog-button>
Attribute [template]
Demo

In this example we have a <gs-dialog-button> that opens a dialog by linking to an external <template> element. This is done by putting the <template>'s [id] in the <gs-dialog-button>'s [template] attribute. You would use this if you want to keep all of your templates together or if you want/have multiple elements/javascript functions using the template. 

<template id="template_example">
    ...
</template>
<gs-dialog-button template="template_example">...</gs-dialog-button>
Event Attributes
Demo

There are four event attributes that you can run JavaScript in for this element.

  • The [before-open] attribute runs before the dialog is added to the DOM. A variable can be used in this attribute is: this, which is the button element that was clicked.
  • The [after-open] attribute runs after the dialog has been added to the DOM. A variable can be used in this attribute is: this, which is the dialog element that was created.
  • The [before-close] attribute runs before the dialog is removed from the DOM. Variables in this attribute are this (which is the dialog element that is going to be closed) and strAnswer (which is the answer of the dialog).
  • The [after-close] attribute runs after the dialog has been removed from the DOM. Variables in this attribute are this (which is the button element that was originally clicked) and strAnswer (which is the answer of the dialog).
 
<gs-dialog-button
    before-open="alert('before-open.');"
    after-open="alert('after-open.');"
    before-close="alert('before-close. Answer: ' + strAnswer);"
    after-close="alert('after-close. Answer: ' + strAnswer);"
>
    ...
</gs-dialog-button>
Attribute [target]
Demo

You can open a dialog and attach it to a target element. This is done by putting a selector in the [target] attribute. This could be used for lists or tooltips. 

<gs-dialog-button target="#target">...</gs-dialog-button>
Attribute [direction]
Demo

You can open a dialog and attach it to a target element. This is done by putting a selector in the [target] attribute. This could be used for lists or tooltips. 

<gs-dialog-button target="#target">...</gs-dialog-button>
GS.closeDialog(...);
Demo

The <template>'s [id] can be used in conjunction with GS.closeDialog(...) to close the dialog with javascript, allowing you to run code before the dialog closes. 

GS.closeDialog('dialog-example', 'Ok');
Attribute [qs]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-dialog-button qs="test1">...</gs-dialog-button>

Checkbox

A checkbox, also known as a tickbox is a clickable box that changes between values when clicked. In most cases the values that the checkbox changes between will be "true" and "false" or "-1" and "0". However, there are two other possibilities: "true", "null" and "false" or "-1", "n" and "0". 

<gs-checkbox>...</gs-checkbox>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic <gs-checkbox> element. Without attributes the checkbox will have the following behaviors:

  1. The checkbox value will start at "false".
  2. The checkbox value will change between "true" and "false".
 
<label for="example_checkbox">This checkbox has an external label.</label>
<gs-checkbox id="example_checkbox"></gs-checkbox>

<gs-checkbox>This checkbox has an internal label.</gs-checkbox>
Attribute [column]
Demo

When you have a <gs-checkbox> inside a data element and you want to use it to display cell data you use the [column] attribute. 

<gs-checkbox column="alive">...</gs-checkbox>

Demo

<gs-checkbox onchange="alert(this.value)">...</gs-checkbox>
Attribute [value]
Demo

Four <gs-checkbox> elements with the [value] attribute set. The [value] attribute determines what type the checkbox uses of value: "true" and "false" or "-1" and "0". The javascript in this example is so you can see the value when you click on the checkbox. 

<gs-checkbox value="true">...</gs-checkbox>
Attribute [type]
Demo

Two <gs-checkbox> elements with the [type] attribute set. The [type] attribute sets the value type of the checkbox. If there is no attribute then it does boolean values: true, false If the attribute is set to smalling then it uses smallint values: -1, 0 The javascript in this example is so you can see the value when you click on the checkbox. 

<gs-checkbox type="smallint">...</gs-checkbox>
Attribute [triplestate]
Demo

Six <gs-checkbox> elements with the [value] and [triplestate] attributes set. The [triplestate] attribute adds the value "null" or "n" depending on the type. The javascript in this example is so you can see the value when you click on the checkbox. 

<gs-checkbox triplestate>...</gs-checkbox>

Demo

With the [disabled] attribute, you can control what order your controls are tabbed to.

Demo

The [disabled] attribute prevents the checkbox from changing. 

<gs-checkbox disabled>...</gs-checkbox>
Attribute [readonly]
Demo

The [readonly] attribute is similar to [disabled] because it prevents the value from changing. The only difference is that [readonly] does not grey out the field and [disabled] does. 

<gs-checkbox readonly>...</gs-checkbox>

Combo

A <gs-combo> is a combination of a textbox and a selectbox. A <gs-combo> fills the need of being able to add custom values into the control. 

<gs-combo></gs-combo>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic <gs-combo> element with list loaded from a Postgres view using the [src=""] attribute. The [src=""] attribute can contain a view name or a table name. When you select a record out of the dropdown the text from the first column will populate the textbox

Demo

To run javascript when the value changes, use the [onchange=""] attribute.

Attribute [hide=""]
Demo

The [hide=""] attribute is for hiding columns that you don't want the user to see but still want access to. The primary use of this attribute is to hide the ID column in such a way that it can be used to get and set the combobox but the user never sees it.

Demo

The [offset=""] attribute is for sending a postgres OFFSET with the view or table in the [src=""] or [initialize=""] attributes. The [ord=""] attribute is for making the data in the combobox clearer and the [limit=""] attribute is so that the offset has an effect.

Datetime

The <gs-dt> control is like the <gs-text> control, but it is specialized for dates and times.

When working with dates on a website we heavily prefer slash delimited dates because a dash delimited date (in some cases) will text wrap, and you want everything to be consistent so please use slash delimited dates.

Values containing dashes do not work unless supplied in an isodate format. 

<gs-dt></gs-dt>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic <gs-dt> element. Without attributes the gs-dt control will have the following behaviors:

  1. Clicking into the date will select the date.
  2. Arrowing up or down will increase or decrease the value of the date depending on the part you have selected.
  3. Arrowing left or right will select the next or previous part.
  4. Pressing any number will overwrite the number of the part you have selected.
 
<gs-dt></gs-dt>
Attribute [column]
Demo

When you have a gs-dt inside a data element and you want to use it to display cell data you use the column attribute. 

<gs-dt column="..."></gs-dt>

<gs-dt onchange="..."></gs-dt>

Demo

To set the value for the <gs-dt>, use the [value=""] attribute. 

<gs-dt value="..."></gs-dt>

Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.

Demo

With the [tabindex=""] attribute, you can control what order your controls are tabbed to. 

<gs-dt tabindex="..."></gs-dt>
Attribute [disabled]
Demo

With the [disabled] attribute, you can control whether or not you can use the control. 

<gs-dt disabled></gs-dt>
Attribute [readonly]
Demo

The [readonly] attribute is similar to [disabled] because it prevents the value from changing. The only difference is that [readonly] does not grey out the field and [disabled] does. 

<gs-dt readonly></gs-dt>
Attribute [format]
Demo

The [format] attribute describes how the date you want to edit is structured.

The following format names are accepted:

Name Example
01/01/2015
shortdate 1/1/15
mediumdate Jan 1, 2015
longdate January 1, 2015
fulldate Thursday, January 1, 2015
isodate 2015-01-01
isodatetime 2015-01-01T00:00:00
shorttime 1:00 AM
mediumtime 01:00:00 AM
isotime 01:00:00

You can specify your own format with these specifiers:

Name Output
y Full year
yyyy Full year
yy Last two digits of the year
M Month number
MM Padded month number
MMM Short month name
MMMM Full month name
d Day of the month
dd Padded day of the month
EEE Short day name
EEEE Full day name
H Hour number (24-hour, midnight 0)
HH Padded hour number (24-hour, midnight 0)
h Hour number (12-hour)
hh Padded hour number (12-hour)
a AM/PM
m Minutes
mm Padded minutes
s Seconds
ss Padded seconds
S Milliseconds
SS Padded milliseconds (length 2)
SSS Padded milliseconds (length 3) 

<gs-dt format="..."></gs-dt>

Interval

The <gs-interval> control is like the <gs-text> control, but it is specialized for amounts of time. 

<gs-interval></gs-interval>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic <gs-interval> element. Without attributes the <gs-interval> control will have the following behaviors:

  1. There is a button that activates the time picker.
  2. After choosing a time with the time picker, the time picker disappears and the data changes in the control.
  3. You can also change the time manually.
  4. The [value=""] attribute will contain the amount of time with minute precision.
 
<gs-interval></gs-interval>
Attribute [column]
Demo

When you have a gs-interval inside a data element and you want to use it to display cell data you use the column attribute. 

<gs-interval column="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [value=""]
Demo

To set the value for the <gs-interval>, use the [value=""] attribute. 

<gs-interval value="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [unit=""]
Demo

The <gs-interval> defaults to treating it's value as a number of minutes. However, you may need to more or less precision than that. To store using hour or second precision you need to adjust the unit that this control uses to translate/store it's value in. To do this you can use the [unit=""] attribute. 

<gs-interval unit="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [hour-places=""]
Demo

To change the number of hours that can be shown in the <gs-interval> use the [hour-places=""] attribute. 

<gs-interval hour-places="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [onchange=""]
Demo

To run javascript when the value changes you can use the [onchange=""] attribute. 

<gs-interval onchange="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-interval qs="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [mini]
Demo

Sometimes you are limited on space. The [mini] attribute can be used to make the <gs-interval> smaller by removing the borders and padding. 

<gs-interval mini></gs-interval>
Attribute [no-picker]
Demo

If you want to remove the time picker button, simply add the [no-picker] attribute. 

<gs-interval no-picker></gs-interval>
Attribute [tabindex=""]
Demo

With the [tabindex=""] attribute, you can control what order your controls are tabbed to. 

<gs-interval tabindex="..."></gs-interval>
Attribute [disabled]
Demo

With the [disabled] attribute, you can control whether or not you can use the control. 

<gs-interval disabled></gs-interval>
Attribute [readonly]
Demo

The [readonly] attribute is similar to [disabled] because it prevents the value from changing. The only difference is that [readonly] does not grey out the field and [disabled] does. 

<gs-interval readonly></gs-interval>
Javascript Methods
Demo

These functions can be run on individual <gs-interval> elements:

INTERVAL.open() <-- This method opens the <gs-interval>. 

intervalElement.open();

Listbox

Listboxes are similar to option boxes in that there is a list and one item from the list can be selected at any given time. Some of the differences are that the listbox can load data from the database, it tries to display full height and it can have a custom template. 

<gs-listbox></gs-listbox>
Skeleton
Demo

A basic <gs-listbox> element with a view source. The minimum <gs-listbox> will have the following behaviors:

  1. Column names are pulled from the database.
  2. Selecting a record will highlight it.
 
<gs-listbox src="..."></gs-listbox>
Attribute [onchange=""]
Demo

To run javascript when the value changes, use the [onchange=""] attribute. 

<gs-listbox onchange="..."></gs-listbox>
Attribute [tabindex=""]
Demo

With the [tabindex=""] attribute, you can control what order your controls are tabbed to. 

<gs-listbox tabindex="..."></gs-listbox>
Static List
Demo

Sometimes you only want to have a static list, this can be done with a template element inside the listbox. The template needs to contain an HTML table. To have a hidden value: put the hidden value in the [value=""] attribute of the <tr> element. 

<gs-listbox>
    <template>
        <table>
            <tbody>
                <tr><td>value 1</td></tr>
                <tr value="hidden value"><td<value 2</td></tr>
                <tr><td>value 3</td></tr>
                <tr><td>value 4</td></tr>
                <tr><td>value 5</td></tr>
                <tr><td>value 6</td></tr>
            </tbody>
        </table>
    </template>
</gs-listbox>
Attribute [cols=""]
Demo

Sometimes you only want certain columns, using the [cols=""] attribute allows you to specify just the columns you want. 

<gs-listbox cols="..."></gs-listbox>
Attribute [where=""]
Demo

You can specify a PostgreSQL WHERE clause using [where=""]. 

<gs-listbox where="..."></gs-listbox>
Attribute [ord=""]
Demo

You can specify a PostgreSQL ORDER BY clause using [ord=""]. 

<gs-listbox ord="..."></gs-listbox>
Attributes [limit=""] & [offset=""]
Demo

You can specify a PostgreSQL LIMIT and OFFSET clause using [limit=""] and [offset=""]. 

<gs-listbox offset="..." limit="..."></gs-listbox>
Custom Template
Demo

In this example we are specifing a custom template for the listbox to use. This allows you to have more control over the look of your listbox. Notice: the [value=""] attribute on the <tr> element will be what you get when you get the value of the listbox; If you don't set the [value=""] attribute on the <tr> than the value will be the text of first column. 

<gs-listbox src="gsdoc.tpeople">
    <template>
        <table>
            <tbody>
                <tr value="{{! row.id }}">
                    <td>
                        ...
                    </td>
                </tr>
            </tbody>
        </table>
    </template>
</gs-listbox>
Attribute [value=""]
Demo

You can specify the default selected record using the [value=""] attribute. 

<gs-listbox value="..."></gs-listbox>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-listbox qs="..."></gs-listbox>
Attribute [disabled]
Demo

You can prevent selection and grey out the <gs-listbox> using the [disabled] attribute. 

<gs-listbox disabled></gs-listbox>
Attribute [no-select]
Demo

You can prevent selection using the [no-select] attribute. 

<gs-listbox no-select></gs-listbox>
Attribute [letter-scrollbar]
Demo

For large listboxes, you can add a scrollbar composed of letters. When you click on a letter, it skips to the first record that begins with that letter. (This only works for the first column. We hid the id column so that it would use the first_name.) Typically you would sort on the first column as well. 

<gs-listbox letter-scrollbar></gs-listbox>
Attribute [letter-dividers]
Demo

You can also add a divider wherever the first letter changes. This can be used with the [letter-scrollbar] attribute. 

<gs-listbox letter-dividers></gs-listbox>
Letter Scrollbar and Dividers
Demo

Typical example of both [letter-scrollbar] and [letter-dividers] 

<gs-listbox letter-scrollbar letter-dividers></gs-listbox>
Refresh On Query String Column Change
Demo

If you want to refresh on changes to a list of columns you can put a comma seperated list of columns in the [refresh-on-querystring-values=""] attribute. That could look something like [refresh-on-querystring-values="parent_id,id"]. 

<gs-listbox refresh-on-querystring-values=""></gs-listbox>
Refresh On Query String Change
Demo

To make the <gs-listbox> refresh when anything in the query string is updated, you add the attribute [refresh-on-querystring-change]. 

<gs-listbox refresh-on-querystring-change></gs-listbox>
Javascript Methods
Demo

These functions that can be run on individual <gs-listbox> elements:

LISTBOX.refresh() <-- This method refeshes the <gs-listbox>.

LISTBOX.scrollToSelectedRecord() <-- This method scrolls the <gs-listbox> to the currently selected record. 

listboxElement.refresh();
listboxElement.scrollToSelectedRecord();

Attribute [pre]
Demo

Use the [pre] attribute to format the text. Note that a \n in the [value=""] attribute will show as \n, but a newline in the attribute text will show properly. 

<gs-static pre>...</gs-static>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-static qs="...">...</gs-static>
Attribute [inline]
Demo

Sometimes you are limited on space. The [inline] attribute can be used to make the <gs-static> smaller width-wise. 

<gs-static inline>...</gs-static>
Attribute [mini]
Demo

Sometimes you are limited on space. The [mini] attribute can be used to make the <gs-static> smaller height-wise. 

<gs-static mini>...</gs-static>

  1. Clicking on the control gives you a cursor.
  2. You can change the text by typing.

Demo

To set the default value for the <gs-text>, use the [value=""] attribute.

Attribute [encrypted="keyVariable"]
Demo

When you have a database column that contains sensitive information use the [encrypted] attribute to encrypt the value. The column will be encrypted with AES using the global variable that matches the [encrypted] attribute. If the gs-text detects a bad password, it will emit a password-error event with the key variable in event.keyVariable and either 'bad' or 'no' in event.reason. The password for this example is 'test'. 

<gs-text encrypted="..."></gs-text>
