Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). Demo

Attribute [disabled]
Demo

With the [disabled] attribute, you can control whether or not you can use the control. Disabled still allows you to copy the current text. 

<gs-text disabled></gs-text>
Attribute [readonly]
Demo

The [readonly] attribute is similar to [disabled] because it prevents the value from changing. The only difference is that [readonly] does not grey out the field and [disabled] does.

To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). Delete Record Button

On receiving the click event, this button deletes a record from a table.

On the click event, this button will run an Websocket DELETE call. A Websocket DELETE is part of the Envelope API. It converts the browser request into a SQL DELETE query and executes it, thereby dropping a record or records. Default functionality includes a popup for confirming you wish to delete the record as well as an error popup if the delete fails to occur.

The gs-delete-button is both click and tap aware and works as expected across desktop and mobile browsers. Note that href, target, and dialogclose attributes won't work for gs-delete-button but other button attributes should work as expected. 

<gs-delete-button></gs-delete-button>
Table/View
Demo

We've set the [src=""] attribute to a view but we could have set it to a table. The user must have delete permission on the table or view for this to work.

Start by clicking the delete button. The record with an "id" column value of "1234" does not exist so this will fail. Next, click the "Add record" button and then the delete button will be updated with a valid record ID. Now you can click the delete button and it will succeed in deleting the record you just created. 

<gs-delete-button src="..." column="..." value="...">...</gs-delete-button>
Attribute [key=""]
Demo

In this example we have a delete button with the [key=""] attribute set. The [key=""] attribute is for defining a hot-key for a button. Note: you have to click into the example for it to work. 

<gs-delete-button key="...">...</gs-delete-button>
Attribute [no-modifier-key]
Demo

In this example we have a button with the "key" and "no-modifier-key" attributes set. The "no-modifier-key" attribute means that you can't use CMD or CTRL to activate the hot-key. Note: you have to click into the example for it to work. 

<gs-delete-button key="..." no-modifier-key>...</gs-delete-button>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

In this example we've set the [qs=""] attribute instead of the column attribute. The [qs=""] attribute has more functionality than this, click here to see the documentation for the rest. 

<gs-delete-button qs="...">...</gs-delete-button>

FORM.removeMessage(strMessageName) <-- This method remove the small message at the top of the <gs-form>.

Datasheet

This element is used for showing data in a spreadsheet. It also has the ability to SELECT, UPDATE and DELETE records. 

<gs-datasheet></gs-datasheet>
Skeleton
Demo

This is an example of a basic, stand-alone gs-datasheet.

Note that the default behavior is for the user to have access to UPDATE and DELETE functionality. If your SRC is a view or function you'll need RULEs or TRIGGERS for UPDATE and DELETE or your users will get errors when they attempt to UPDATE or DELETE records.

Other default behaviors include the refresh button. Row numbers are provided by datasheet when your template includes {{! row_number }}.

The copy functionality allows you to select contiguous cells by clicking and dragging (or by selecting a cell, holding down shift and selecting another cell). You can select individual cells by holding down Command. You can drag across columns to select just a section of a table.

The "pk" attribute defines the PRIMARY KEY column of the object. 

<gs-datasheet src="...">
    <template for="table">
        <table>
            <tbody>
                <tr>
                    <th heading="#">
                        {{! row_number }}
                    </th>
                    <td heading="...">
                        ...
                    </td>
                </tr>
            </tbody>
        </table>
    </template>
</gs-datasheet>
Attribute [cols=""]
Demo

The [cols=""] attribute helps to limit the number of columns coming back from the database. This can reduce the amount of data that the server has to process and send to the WebSocket. 

<gs-datasheet cols="...">...</gs-datasheet>
Attribute [caption=""]
Demo

The [caption=""] attribute provides a caption at the top of the datasheet. 

<gs-datasheet caption="...">...</gs-datasheet>
Attribute [qs=""]
Demo

The name [qs] stands for "querystring". The querystring is the part in the URL after the "?". The [qs] attribute has two formats, each with their own use.

  • qs="key1=attribute1". This format allows you to fill any attribute with any key from the querystring. To use multiple keys from the querystring you can put a comma-separated list of these expressions (for example: qs="key1=attribute1,key2=attribute2"). If you need an attribute to be added when a querystring key is not present, replace the "=" with "!=" (for example: qs="key1!=attribute1", attribute1 will only be added if key1 is not in the querystring). As a shorthand, if the key in the querystring is the same name as the attribute you want to fill, you can omit the attribute name in the expression (for example: qs="key1="). If an expression doesn't find it's key in the querystring: it reverts the attribute that it fills to it's original value.
  • qs="key". This format will update the [value] attribute with the querystring whenever the querystring changes.
 
<gs-datasheet qs="...">...</gs-datasheet>
SQL Attributes
Demo

The [where=""], [ord=""], [limit=""] and [offset=""] attributes are used to configure which and how many records you want the datasheet to get.

  • The [where=""] attribute takes any WHERE clause.
  • The [ord=""] attribute takes any ORDER BY clause.
  • The [limit=""] attribute takes an integer and LIMITs the number of records that the datasheet asks for.
  • The [offset=""] attribute takes an integer and OFFSETs the results.
 
<gs-datasheet where="...">...</gs-datasheet>
<gs-datasheet ord="...">...</gs-datasheet>
<gs-datasheet limit="...">...</gs-datasheet>
<gs-datasheet offset="...">...</gs-datasheet>

    </template>

In this example the datasheet has the [reflow-at=""] attribute. The [reflow-at=""] attribute is for telling the datasheet when to reflow the table. When a table is "reflowed" that means that each record is essentially turned to be vertical. To put a heading above each of the controls you must have the "heading" attribute set for each cell.

Header And Line Relationship Attributes
Demo

In this example we have a form with an datasheet inside that has the [column=""] and [child-column=""] attributes set, it also gets it's [value=""] attribute set by the form. Each of these three attributes are used to filter the datasheet based on a header record.

The [column=""] Attribute:
This attribute is for getting the value from the form and it (in the absence of the [child-column=""] attribute) is used as the column name that the datasheet filters on.

The [child-column=""] Attribute:
This attribute is the name of the column that you want to filter on and insert with. If this is not set it defaults to the value of the "column" attribute.

The [value=""] Attribute:
This attribute works in conjunction with the [column=""] and [child-column=""] attributes to be the value that the datasheet filters for. 

<gs-datasheet column="..." child-column="...">...</gs-datasheet>
<gs-datasheet value="...">...</gs-datasheet>
Attribute [refresh-on-querystring-values=""]
Demo

The [refresh-on-querystring-values=""] attribute refreshes the datasheet when any of the columns in the attribute change in the query string. To put multiple columns in the attribute you would just put in a comma seperated list. 

<gs-datasheet refresh-on-querystring-values="...">...</gs-datasheet>
Attribute [refresh-on-querystring-change]
Demo

The [refresh-on-querystring-change] attribute refreshes the form element when anything changes in the query string. 

<gs-datasheet refresh-on-querystring-change>...</gs-datasheet>
Javascript Methods
Demo

These functions can be run on individual datasheet elements:

datasheet.refresh() <- This method refreshes the data inside the datasheet.

datasheet.refreshReflow() <- This method recalculates to see if the datasheet should be reflowed or not. The effects of this method are only visible when for some reason the datasheet changed width to the point of needing to reflow or un-reflow but was not refreshed because the window "resize" event was not triggered.

datasheet.refreshFixedHeader() <- This method refreshes the widths of the datasheet header. The effects of this method are only visible when for some reason the datasheet changed width but the headers were not refreshed because the window "resize" event was not triggered. 

datasheetElement.refresh();
datasheetElement.refreshReflow();
datasheetElement.refreshFixedHeader();
Getting The Current Selection
Demo

For this example you will have to open the Javascript console for your browser.

There are three ways to get the selection of an datasheet:

datasheet.selectedCells; <- This will return an array of cell elements that are selected.

datasheet.selectedRecords; <- This will return an array of record elements that contain selected cells.

datasheet.selectedIds; <- This will return an array of record IDs where the corresponding record element contains selected cells.

There are three ways to set the selection of an datasheet:

datasheet.selectedCells = ...; <- The format that this requires is an array of table cell elements that are inside the datasheet you are setting the selection of.

datasheet.selectedRecords = ...; <- The format that this requires is an array of record elements that are inside the datasheet you are setting the selection of.

datasheet.selectedIds = ...; <- The format that this requires is an array of record IDs that are inside the datasheet you are setting the selection of. 

datasheetElement.selectedCells;
datasheetElement.selectedRecords;
datasheetElement.selectedIds;
Events
Demo

In this example we have an datasheet that logs every event that we have built in:

after_selection: This event is triggered when the cell selection of the datasheet changes.

after_select: This event is triggered when the element receives the data, if there is not error.

after_update: This event is triggered when the element receives confirmation that an update has gone through.

after_delete: This event is triggered when the element receives confirmation that a delete has gone through.

after_insert: This event is triggered when the element receives confirmation that an insert has gone through.

insert_dialog_open: This event is triggered when the insert dialog has been opened. 

datasheetElement.addEventListener('after_selection', function () {});
datasheetElement.addEventListener('after_select', function () {});
datasheetElement.addEventListener('after_update', function () {});
datasheetElement.addEventListener('after_delete', function () {});
datasheetElement.addEventListener('after_insert', function () {});
datasheetElement.addEventListener('insert_dialog_open', function () {});

<gs-datasheet>
    <template for="table">
        <table>
            <tbody>

                        ...
                    </td>

                                                ...
                                            </td>
                                        </tr>
                                    </tbody>
                                </table>
                            </template>
                        </gs-datasheet>
                    </td>
                </tr>
            </tbody>
        </table>
    </template>
</gs-datasheet>

Table

This element is used for having datasheeting editing on large tables. 

<gs-table></gs-table>
 Here is the basic anatomy of a data-connected gs-table element: 
<gs-table id="TABLEID" src="TABLESRC">
    <template for="top-hud">

Attributes:
Attribute Name Required Explanation
id="A" YES Used to differentiate the table from all other tables.
src="A" YES, if no "columns" attr Defines what POSTGRES view or table to connect to.
columns="A,A,A" YES, if no "src" attr If there is a "src", this attribute limits what columns are retrieved.
If there is no "src", this defines the column structure for the local table.
session-filter="A" NO This is a where clause that is overridable by the user.
seq="A" NO Defines the sequence to pull from for insert calls.
no-record-selector NO Removes record selector.
no-insert-scroll NO Prevents automatically scrolling to a newly inserted line.
default-record-height="A" NO Set's initial record height. Pixel size only.
default-column-width="A" NO Set's default column width. Pixel size only.
copy-quote-char="A" NO Defines what character is used for quoting in the the CSV copy mode.
copy-escape-char="A" NO Defines what character is used for escaping control characters in the the CSV copy mode.
copy-null-cell="A" NO Defines what string is used for representing null in the the CSV copy mode.
copy-quote-when="never|strings|always|delimiter-in-content" NO Defines when a cell is quoted.
copy-header="never|always|selected" NO Defines when copying a header is allowed.
copy-selectors="never|always|selected" NO Defines when copying a selector is allowed.
copy-delimiter-record="{{DOS_RETURN}},{{MAC_RETURN}},A" NO Defines record delimiter in CSV copy mode. Special values are {{DOS_RETURN}} (\r\n) and {{MAC_RETURN}} (\n).
copy-delimiter-cell="{{DOS_RETURN}},{{MAC_RETURN}},A" NO Defines column delimiter in CSV copy mode. Special values are {{DOS_RETURN}} (\r\n) and {{MAC_RETURN}} (\n).
copy-types="text,html" NO Defines what copy modes are used. One or both may be used at the same time.
qs="A" NO
pk="A" NO Defines which column is used as a primary key.
lock="A" NO Defines which column or columns (comma separated) are used to determine if someone else updated the record before we do whatever operation we want to it.
ord="A" NO Defines a Postgres ORDER BY.
where="A" NO Defines a Postgres WHERE.
limit="A" NO Defines a Postgres LIMIT.
offset="A" NO Defines a Postgres OFFSET.
focus-on-load NO If this attribute is present, the table will attempt to gain the focus on page load.
column="A" NO Used for parent-child relationships. This is the parent column.
child-column="A" NO Used for parent-child relationships. This is the child column.
null-string="A" NO Defines what string is used to show null to the user.
null-set-string="A" NO Defines what string is given by the user to set a cell to null.


Pitfalls to watch out for:
  • Slow control elements
  • Scrollbars within cells are slow

Flex Attributes

These attributes are shortcuts for using CSS Flexbox functionality. For documentation about Flexbox itself: MDN, CSS-Tricks. 

flex-vertical
flex-horizontal
flex
flex-fill
flex-center
align-top
align-center
align-bottom
wrap
wrap-reverse
justify-start
justify-end
justify-center
justify-space-between
justify-space-around
Attribute [flex-vertical]
Demo

In this example we have a div that has been set to full height that also has the [flex-vertical] attribute. The [flex-vertical] attribute makes it so that the children of the div are orientated vertically. 

<div flex-vertical>...</div>
Attribute [flex-horizontal]
Demo

In this example we have a div that has the [flex-horizontal] attribute. The [flex-horizontal] attribute makes it so that the children of the div are orientated horizontally. 

<div flex-horizontal>...</div>
Attribute [flex]
Demo

In this example we have two divs: one has the [flex-vertical] attribute and one has the [flex-horizontal] attribute and both of them have a child with the [flex] attribute. The [flex] attribute makes that child fill the unused room in the direction that the parent is set to. 

<div flex-vertical>
    <div flex>...</div>
</div>
<div flex-horizontal>
    <div flex>...</div>
</div>
Attribute [flex-fill]
Demo

In this example we have two divs: one has the [flex-vertical] attribute and one has the [flex-horizontal] attribute and both of them have the [flex-fill] and a child with the [flex] attribute. The [flex-fill] attribute makes the children of the two divs take up all unused room in the directions that are opposite of the directions that the divs are set to (so for [flex-vertical] the children take up all of the unused horizontal room and for [flex-horizontal] the children take up all of the unused vertical room). 

<div flex-vertical flex-fill>
    <div flex>...</div>
</div>
<div flex-horizontal flex-fill>
    <div flex>...</div>
</div>
Attribute [flex-center]
Demo

In this example we have a div that has the [flex-horizontal] attribute and the [flex-center] attribute. The [flex-center] attribute centers the children in the very middle of the parent. 

<div flex-horizontal flex-center>...</div>
Alignment Attributes
Demo

In this example we have three divs with the [flex-horizontal] attribute. The first div also has the [align-top] attribute which makes it so that the children go to the top. The second div also has the [align-center] attribute which makes it so that the children go to the center. The third div also has the [align-bottom] attribute which makes it so that the children go to the bottom. 

<div flex-horizontal align-top>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal align-center>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal align-bottom>...</div>
Wrapping Attributes
Demo

In this example we have two divs with the [flex-horizontal] attribute. The first div also has the [wrap] attribute which makes it so that the children wrap onto multiple lines if they cannot be displayed in one line. The second div also has the [wrap-reverse] attribute which makes it so that the lines are in reverse order. 

<div flex-horizontal wrap>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal wrap-reverse>...</div>
Justification Attributes
Demo

In this example we have five divs each with the [flex-horizontal] attribute. We have five attributes to change the justification of the divs.

  • justify-start: all divs are justified to the left
  • justify-end: all divs are justified to the right
  • justify-center: all divs are justified to the center
  • justify-space-between: all divs have equal space between them, the first and last divs have no space from the edges of the parent
  • justify-space-around: all divs have equal space between them and half space on the edges of the parent

These same attributes can work on a vertical-flex parent as well. 

<div flex-horizontal justify-start>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal justify-end>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal justify-center>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal justify-space-between>...</div>
<div flex-horizontal justify-space-around>...</div>

Standard Ajax

These functions used for traditional, callback-based ajax calls. 

GS.ajaxJSON(<LINK>, <PARAMETERS>, <CALLBACK>, <FRONT-END-TIMEOUT>);
GS.ajaxText(<LINK>, <PARAMETERS>, <CALLBACK>);
Function GS.ajaxJSON()
Demo

The GS.ajaxJSON function makes an ajax call and expects only valid JSON to come back from the server. If no valid JSON comes back it is considered an error. The data that is returned is given to the javascript callback as a Javascript Object. In this example we are passing the "gsdoc.action_ajax_test_json" function a parameter string and the function is returning it back to us. Note: we are returning the parameter string with double quotes around it so that it be valid when it is put into the JSON response. You could also return a JSON object of your own if it is a valid JSON. 

GS.ajaxJSON('...', '...', function () {...});
Function GS.ajaxText()
Demo

The GS.ajaxText function makes an ajax call and expects text to come back from the server. The data that is returned is given to the javascript callback as a string. Note: the "accept_" type of function expects you to return the response headers. 

GS.ajaxText('...', '...', function () {...});
Ajax Error Handling
Demo

The GS.ajaxJSON and GS.ajaxText functions both use the same system for ajax error handling. 

GS.ajaxJSON('...', '...', function () {
    // if there was no error
    if (!error) {
        // do stuff here
        
    // else there was no error
    } else {
        GS.ajaxErrorDialog(data);
    }
});
GS.ajaxJSON Front End Timeout
Demo

The GS.ajaxJSON function has an optional parameter for timing out in the front end. The parameter takes a number of milliseconds and if that amount of time has been reached and the ajax still hasn't returned: it aborts the ajax call. In this example the ajax call has been set to timeout after 5 seconds (5000 milliseconds) and the function we are testing with is set to run for 10 seconds long before returning. 

GS.ajaxText('...', '...', function () {...}, ...);

Duplicate Safe Ajax

The GS.dataFetch function is for making duplicate ajax calls use the same ajax call. Essentially the data is cached after the first request unless it is cleared. The main use of this function is when you have a combobox in a table and each combobox will have the same data so instead of one ajax call for each combobox all of the comboboxes use the same ajax call. 

GS.dataFetch('...');
Skeleton
Demo

In this example we have minimal usage of GS.dataFetch. When you click the "Run Ajax" the first time it will make a call to the database and you'll notice a loader pop up. Subsequent clicks to the button will be instantaneous because it will be getting that data from a variable on the page instead of from the database. 

GS.dataFetch('...');
Clear
Demo

In this example we have two buttons: one to make the call and cache the rest and one to clear the cache and to make the call. 

GS.dataFetch('...', true);

Ajax Error Dialog

An error dialog for the ajaxJSON callback. 

GS.ajaxErrorDialog(jsnError[, tryAgainCallback[, cancelCallback]]);
Skeleton
Demo

A basic error dialog. the will have the following behaviors:

  • It will show the user an error.
  • It will allow them to try again.
 
GS.ajaxJSON('...', '...', function (data, error) {
    if (!error) {
        // Do stuff
    } else {
        GS.ajaxErrorDialog(data, function () {
            //Here call the original function that run's your GS.ajaxJSON
        });
    }
});
No Callback
Demo

This will not allow the user to try again, because there is no callback passed to the function. 

GS.ajaxJSON('...', '...', function (data, error) {
    if (!error) {
        // Do stuff
    } else {
        GS.ajaxErrorDialog(data);
    }
});

String Padding

The GS.rightPad and GS.leftPad functions are for adding characters to a string to make it a certain length or longer. The primary use of this is for when creating a text representation of a date object. You may want a date that looks like this: "1-1-2015" to look like this: "01-01-2015" or you may want a date that looks like this: "12-1-2015" to look like this: "12-01-2015". This is created using padding functions. 

GS.rightPad(<STRING-TO-PAD>, <STRING-TO-PAD-WITH>, <LENGTH-TO-PAD-TO>);
GS.leftPad(<STRING-TO-PAD>, <STRING-TO-PAD-WITH>, <LENGTH-TO-PAD-TO>);
Skeleton
Demo

This is a basic example of GS.rightPad and GS.leftPad. The four character string "test" will be padded by asterisks to be six characters long. 

GS.rightPad('...', '...', ...);
GS.leftPad('...', '...', ...);
Date String
Demo

This is an example of using GS.leftPad to pad the numbers in a date string. 

GS.leftPad(testDate.getMonth() + 1, '0', 2)
+ '/'
+ GS.leftPad(testDate.getDate(), '0', 2)
+ '/'
+ (testDate.getFullYear())

Safe URI Decoding

The GS.safeDecodeURIComponent runs the Javascript decodeURIComponent function but when it runs into a decoding error it just returns the string it was sent without any modifications. So if the string "asdf%26asdf" was sent than it would return "asdf&asdf" but if the string "asdf%z2asdf" was sent it would return the same string because "%z2" is not a valid URI code. See also: URL State Functions and Query String. 

GS.safeDecodeURIComponent(<STRING-TO-DECODE>);
Skeleton
Demo

When you click the "Safe" button the text of the first text control will be run through the GS.safeDecodeURIComponent() function and put in the second text control. When you click the "Not Safe" button the text of the first text control will be run through the decodeURIComponent function and put in the second text control. If there is an error when decodeURIComponent is run than the error text will be put into the second text control. 

GS.safeDecodeURIComponent('...');

Query String

A querystring is a data structure in the format of: "COLUMN=VALUE&COLUMN2=VALUE2". Notice that there are column/value pairs and the pairs are seperated by ampersands. Columns may also be called keys for shortness.

These functions are used for reading, converting, generating and altering querystrings. See also: Safe URI Decoding and URL State Functions. 

GS.getQueryString();
GS.qryToJSON(<QUERYSTRING-TO-CONVERT>);
GS.qryFromJSON(<JSON-TO-CONVERT>);
GS.qryToWhere(<QUERYSTRING>[, <COLUMN-IN-QUERYSTRING>[, <COLUMN-IN-TARGET>]]);
GS.qryGetKeys(<QUERYSTRING>);
GS.qryGetVals(<QUERYSTRING>);
GS.qryDeleteKey(<QUERYSTRING>, <COLUMN-TO-DELETE>);
GS.qryGetVal(<QUERYSTRING>, <COLUMN-TO-GET>);
GS.qrySetVal(<QUERYSTRING>, <COLUMN=NEWVALUE>);
GS.getQueryString
Demo

This function returns the querystring from the window. 

GS.getQueryString();
GS.qryToJSON
Demo

This function converts a querystring to a JSON object. 

GS.qryToJSON('...');
GS.qryFromJSON
Demo

This function turns a JSON object into a querystring. 

GS.qryFromJSON(objToBeConverted);
GS.qryToWhere
Demo

This function converts a querystring to a Postgres WHERE clause 

GS.qryToWhere(GS.getQueryString(), '...', '...');
GS.qryGetKeys
Demo

This function returns an array of all the columns in a querystring. 

GS.qryGetKeys(GS.getQueryString());
GS.qryGetVals
Demo

This function returns an array of all the values in a querystring. 

GS.qryGetVals(GS.getQueryString());
GS.qryDeleteKey
Demo

This function removes a column/value pair from a querystring. 

GS.qryDeleteKey(strQueryString, '...');
GS.qryGetVal
Demo

This function gets a value from a querystring based on a column. 

GS.qryGetVal(GS.getQueryString(), '...');
GS.qrySetVal
Demo

This function sets a value in a querystring. 

GS.qrySetVal(strQueryString, '...');

Add Before Unload Event

Javascript has a feature which allows the developer to run code before the page unloads, this is used primarily as a means of opening up a popup asking to confirm if you want to close the page. This feature is accessed using the window.onbeforeunload property. However there is a limitation of this property: you cannot run two independent functions using the same property.

This function was created to allow multiple "onbeforeunload" functions to run. Just call the function and send your function that you want to bind and it'll add it to the stack. 

GS.addBeforeUnloadEvent(function () {...});

Find Parent

These functions are for finding a parent element of a specified element. 

GS.findParentTag(<ELEMENT-TO-SEARCH-FROM>, <TAG-NAME>);
GS.findParentElement(<ELEMENT-TO-SEARCH-FROM>, <SELECTOR|FUNCTION|ELEMENT>);
GS.findParentTag
Demo

This function finds a parent using the tag name. It loops through parents and stops when it finds the first element with the specified tag name. In this example you choose a tag to find using the select box and when you click the "Find Parent" button it will find the parent with that tag and put a CSS border on it. 

GS.findParentTag(target, '...');
GS.findParentElement Selector

Get Style

This function is for getting a "computed" CSS property of an element. The "computed" style is the style that the browser decides on after reading the CSS. So if "background-color" is set three times on the same element and the browser chooses to use the third which we'll just say is "#0F0" (solid green) that would be the computed style. Notice: the browser may translate the choosen value to another format so it may turn "#0F0" into "rgb(0, 255, 0)" and that'll show through as the computed style. 

GS.getStyle(<ELEMENT>, <CSS-PROPERTY>);
GS.getStyle
Demo

In this example when you click the "Get Target 1 Style" button the "result" div will be populated with the computed "background-color" style of the "Target 1" element. When you click the "Get Target 2 Style" button the "result" div will be populated with the computed "background-color" style of the "Target 2" element. 

GS.getStyle(target, '...');

Copy Settings
Demo

You can alter how the text copy works using a set of attributes.

  • "quote-type" this controls what values are quoted. There are three possible values for this attribute: "all", "none", "strings". "all" means put quotes around every value. "none" means put quotes around nothing value. "strings" means put quotes around everything that isn't a number.
  • "quote-char" this sets the character used to quote a value.
  • "field-delimiter" this sets the character used to seperate fields.
  • "null-values" this sets the what string is used instead when the value of a cell is "NULL" or "\N".
  • "column-names" this is a true/false attribute. "true" means that when you copy you'll always get the column headings.
  • "row-delimiter" this sets the character used to seperate records.
 
<table quote-type="all" quote-char="'" field-delimiter="," null-values="HELLO" column-names="true">...</table>

Pixel and EM conversion

These functions are for converting from pixels to ems and also ems to pixels. The reason for the <ELEMENT> parameter is that ems are relative to the font-size of parent elements (if you had an element with a font-size of 18 pixels then "1em" would be 18 pixels, "0.5em" would be equal to 9 pixels, "1.5em" would be equal to 27 pixels etc...) so to convert using a specific elements you just change what element you put in the <ELEMENT> parameter. 

GS.pxToEm(<ELEMENT>, <PIXELS-TO-CONVERT>);
GS.emToPx(<ELEMENT>, <EMS-TO-CONVERT>);
GS.pxToEm
Demo

In this example when you click the "Convert To Ems" button the number in the "number-of-px" control will be converted into pixels using the <body> element's font-size. 

GS.pxToEm(target, 123)
GS.emToPx
Demo

In this example when you click the "Convert To Pixels" button the number in the "number-of-em" control will be converted into pixels using the <body> element's font-size. 

GS.emToPx(target, 123)

Authentication

These links handle Envelope authentication, including login, change password, and logout. 

/env/auth
    action=login
    username=<USERNAME>
    password=<PASSWORD>
/env/auth
    action=change_pw
    password_old=<PASSWORD>
    password_new=<NEW-PASSWORD>
/env/auth
    action=logout
/env/action_info
Login
Demo

Before you can use the envelope website, you need to authenticate yourself to the server. The response from the login ajax call will contain your envelope cookie. All cookies have an expiration date and time determined by the envelope config file. The default is eight hours. This prevents someone from using a stolen cookie forever. The ajax call also returns the home page. 

GS.ajaxJSON('/env/auth', 'action=login'
    + '&username=' + encodeURIComponent('...')
    + '&password=' + encodeURIComponent('...'), callback);
Change Password
Demo

Every once in a while, you will want to change your password. This ajax call both changes the password and replaces the envelope cookie. 

GS.ajaxJSON('/env/auth', 'action=change_pw'
    + '&password_old=' + encodeURIComponent('...')
    + '&password_new=' + encodeURIComponent('...'), callback);
Logout
Demo

Once you are done working for the day, logout. Your envelope cookie will be destroyed as a result of this ajax call. Without a cookie further calls to the system will fail. 

GS.ajaxJSON('/env/auth', 'action=logout', callback);
Info
Demo

Returns Username, Groups, envelope version, cluster version, cluster port number and dbname. 

GS.ajaxJSON('/env/action_info', '', callback);

Database

These links handle running postgresql functions.

Envelope provides context info to postgres for functions, access using: current_setting('sunny.context_info')

This returns something like: 

request_ip_address=127.0.0.1&request_host=127.0.0.1%3A8082&user_agent=Mozilla/5.0%20%28Windows%20NT%2010.0%3B%20Win64%3B%20x64%29%20AppleWebKit/537.36%20%28KHTML,%20like%20Gecko%29%20Chrome/57.0.2987.133%20Safari/537.36
 
/env/[<SCHEMA>.]<FUNCTION>[?<ARGS>]
Action
Demo

action_ functions return json. Only functions that start with action_ (or accept_ like in the next example) are allowed. 

GS.ajaxJSON('/env/gsdoc.action_test', 'test=test', callback);
Accept
Demo

accept_ functions return a full response. 

GS.ajaxJSON('/env/gsdoc.accept_test', 'test=test', callback);
Accept Download
Demo

When you want to download a file from the database, sometimes you will want a custom file name. Simply add the filename after the schema.function. That path will be sent to the function as path=/file.txt. 

<form id="form_example" method="post" action="/env/gsdoc.accept_test/file.txt">
    <input type="hidden" name="test" value="test"/>
</form>

    socket, strMessage, callback
);

GS.openSocket
Demo

The "GS.openSocket" function opens a WebSocket to the Envelope Engine. There is no "onopen" event because when you send messages to the socket using the other functions those messages automatically wait until the connection is established before being sent off. 

GS.openSocket('env');
GS.closeSocket
Demo

The "GS.closeSocket" function closes a WebSocket. 

GS.closeSocket(socketObject);
Encode and Decode
Demo

The Envelope Engine transmits data in a tabular format delimiting cells with TAB characters and records with RETURN characters. The "GS.encodeForTabDelimited" and "GS.decodeFromTabDelimited" functions are for encoding and decoding cell values for transmission. Using these functions prevents a TAB (\t), RETURN (\r and/or \n) or BACKSLASH (\) character inside a cell from being misinterpreted as a delimiter. These functions also turn NULL (\N) characters into the string "NULL" and back the other way. 

GS.encodeForTabDelimited('...');
GS.decodeFromTabDelimited('...');
GS.requestFromSocket
Demo

The GS.requestFromSocket function is for making a request from a websocket. 

GS.requestFromSocket(socketObject, '...', callback);
GS.requestActionFromSocket
Demo

The GS.requestActionFromSocket function is for getting data from the database via the Envelope Engine's "ACTION" API. This function calls it's callback once with the action data. 

GS.requestActionFromSocket(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', callback);
GS.requestSelectFromSocket
Demo

The GS.requestSelectFromSocket function is for getting data from the database via the Envelope Engine's "SELECT" API. This function calls it's callback once for each record data or "TRANSACTION COMPLETED" WebSocket frame. 

GS.requestSelectFromSocket(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', callback);
GS.requestCachingSelect
Demo

The GS.requestCachingSelect function is for getting data from the database via the Envelope Engine's "SELECT" API. But, the results cache so that you can consolidate multiple SELECTs that are exactly the same. This is useful if you going to repeat a select call but don't want to bog down the web page with many identical select calls.

The GS.requestCachingSelect function can be told to clear it's cache, if the bolClearCache parameter is set to true then the cache will be cleared for that particular query. 

GS.requestCachingSelect(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', callback);
GS.requestInsertFromSocket
Demo

The GS.requestInsertFromSocket function is for inserting records into a database object.

The function has three steps:

  1. BEGIN a transaction
  2. send your INSERTs
  3. Return after COMMIT/ROLLBACK

Each step has it's own callback:

  1. The BEGIN callback allows you to handle an error at the BEGIN step.
  2. The INSERT callback allows you to:
    • Handle an error at the INSERT step
    • Show the user what the actual records will look like before COMMITing
    • Decide to COMMIT or ROLLBACK the transaction
  3. The COMMIT/ROLLBACK callback allows you to handle the success or error of the COMMIT or ROLLBACK.
 
GS.requestInsertFromSocket(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', objInsertData, callback);
GS.requestUpdateFromSocket
Demo

The GS.requestUpdateFromSocket function is for updating records in a database object.

The function has three steps:

  1. BEGIN a transaction
  2. send your UPDATEs
  3. Return after COMMIT/ROLLBACK

Each step has it's own callback:

  1. The BEGIN callback allows you to handle an error at the BEGIN step.
  2. The UPDATE callback allows you to:
    • Handle an error at the UPDATE step
    • Show the user what the data will look like before COMMITing
    • Decide to COMMIT or ROLLBACK the transaction
  3. The COMMIT/ROLLBACK callback allows you to handle the success or error of the COMMIT or ROLLBACK.
 
GS.requestUpdateFromSocket(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', '...', objUpdateData, callback);
GS.requestDeleteFromSocket
Demo

The GS.requestDeleteFromSocket function is for updating records in a database object.

The function has three steps:

  1. BEGIN a transaction
  2. send your DELETEs
  3. Return after COMMIT/ROLLBACK

Each step has it's own callback:

  1. The BEGIN callback allows you to handle an error at the BEGIN step.
  2. The DELETE callback allows you to:
    • Handle an error at the DELETE step
    • Show the user what the data will look like before COMMITing
    • Decide to COMMIT or ROLLBACK the transaction
  3. The COMMIT/ROLLBACK callback allows you to handle the success or error of the COMMIT or ROLLBACK.
 
GS.requestDeleteFromSocket(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', objDeleteData, callback);
GS.webSocketErrorDialog
Demo

The GS.webSocketErrorDialog function is for opening a dialog when there is an error during a WebSocket call. 

GS.requestSelectFromSocket(socketObject, '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', '...', function (data, error) {
    if (!error) {
        
    } else {
        GS.webSocketErrorDialog(data, tryAgainCallback, cancelCallback);
    }
});

File Creation
Demo

The CREATE_FILE command creates a file at a location that you specify. This command returns the Last Modified Stamp of the new file. If the file already exists, the command will error. 

GS.requestFromSocket(socketObject, 'FILE\tCREATE_FILE\t' + '...', callback);
File Move
Demo

The MOVE command renames/moves a file/folder that you specify to a new path that you specify. This command returns the Last Modified Stamp of the moved file/folder. 

GS.requestFromSocket(socketObject, 'FILE\tMOVE\t' + '...', callback);
File Delete
Demo

The DELETE command deletes a file/folder that you specify. This command returns "OK" if the delete was successful. 

GS.requestFromSocket(socketObject, 'FILE\tDELETE\t' + '...', callback);
File Read
Demo

The READ command returns the Last Modified Stamp and the content of a file that you specify. The first line in the response is the change stamp and the rest after that is content. 

GS.requestFromSocket(socketObject, 'FILE\tREAD\t' + '...', callback);
File Write
Demo

The WRITE command overwrites the content of a file with new content. This command requires the Last Modified Stamp and the new content of the file. This command returns the new Last Modified Stamp of the file. 

GS.requestFromSocket(socketObject, 'FILE\tWRITE\t' + '...', callback);

Script.so

This library will allow you to run bash and perl scripts from postgres. You must create the scripts in your data directory, they must be in /path/to/data/scripts, and they must be owned by root, permissions 750.

We use the secure coding specification from: https://www.securecoding.cert.org

Parameters:
Name Input Optional Description
Stdin Any Yes Usually a file, can be whatever the script can accept.
Arguments URI Encoded Arguements Yes The arguments are converted from uri to -- command line arguments.
How to create a postgres functions that runs /path/to/data/scripts/action_test.plx
-- DROP FUNCTION postage.action_test(text, text);

CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION postage.action_test(text, text)
  RETURNS text AS
    '$libdir/script.so', 'action_script_perl'
  LANGUAGE c VOLATILE STRICT
  COST 1;

ALTER FUNCTION postage.action_test(text, text) OWNER TO postgres;
REVOKE ALL ON FUNCTION postage.action_test(text, text) FROM public;;

--SELECT postage.action_test(text, text);
How to use stdin on action_test.plx
SELECT postage.action_test('The input to the script', '');
What runs in command line:
action_test.plx <EOF
The input to the script
EOF
How to use arguments on action_test.plx
SELECT postage.action_test('', 'arg1=value1&arg2=value2');
What runs in command line:
action_test.plx --arg1=value1 --arg2=value2
How to use both stdin and arguments on action_test.plx
SELECT postage.action_test('The input to the script', 'arg1=value1&arg2=value2');
What runs in command line:
action_test.plx --arg1=value1 --arg2=value2 <EOF
The input to the script
EOF
Perl script example for receiving arguments:
#!/usr/bin/perl -w

use Getopt::Long; #CANNOT USE STRICT WHILE USING THIS CORE MODULE!!! I KNOW IT MAKES NO SENSE!!!
my $to = "";

GetOptions("to=s" => \$to) or die("Error in command line arguments\n");

print "To: " . $to . "\n";
./action_test.plx --to=testing
Bash script example for receiving arguments:
#!/bin/bash
optspec=":hv-:"
while getopts "$optspec" optchar; do
    case "${optchar}" in
        -)
            case "${OPTARG}" in
                loglevel)
                    val="${!OPTIND}"; OPTIND=$(( $OPTIND + 1 ))
                    echo "Parsing option: '--${OPTARG}', value: '${val}'" >&2;
                    ;;
                loglevel=*)
                    val=${OPTARG#*=}
                    opt=${OPTARG%=$val}
                    echo "Parsing option: '--${opt}', value: '${val}'" >&2
                    ;;
                *)
                    if [ "$OPTERR" = 1 ] && [ "${optspec:0:1}" != ":" ]; then
                        echo "Unknown option --${OPTARG}" >&2
                    fi
                    ;;
            esac;;
        h)
            echo "usage: $0 [-v] [--loglevel[=]]" >&2
            exit 2
            ;;
        v)
            echo "Parsing option: '-${optchar}'" >&2
            ;;
        *)
            if [ "$OPTERR" != 1 ] || [ "${optspec:0:1}" = ":" ]; then
                echo "Non-option argument: '-${OPTARG}'" >&2
            fi
            ;;
    esac
done
./action_test.sh --loglevel=testing

Permissions

File permissions are done using PostgreSQL groups. Before you read this page, please read about PostgreSQL permissions. PostgreSQL ROLEs that you want to be able to login to the website need the group trusted_g.

Role (Our name for Document Control)

Types of folders:
  • All
  • Group Folders
  • User Folders

Folder permissions are only checked for the first level.

All Folder:
  • There can be only one all/ folder.
  • Developers can read/write.
  • Everybody with a cookie can read.
Group Folder:
  • Groups should end in _g.
  • The folder name must be the group name. Example: To read the file blog_g/index.html you must have the group blog_g.
  • Developers can read/write.
  • A user with the a group name that ends in _w and a group that end in _g can read and write. Example: To write the file blog_g/index.html you must have the group blog_g and blog_w.
User Folder:
  • Users can have their own folder.
  • The folder name must be the username. Example: To read the file john@example.com/index.html you must be the user john@example.com.
  • Developers can read/write.
  • Nobody else has access.

Dev/Apps, Public/Webroot (Accessed from File Manager)

Types of Folders:
  • All
  • Group Folders
  • User Folders

Folder permissions are only checked for the first level.

All Folder:
  • There can be only one all/ folder.
  • Developers can read/write.
  • Everybody with a cookie can read.
Group Folder:
  • Groups should end in _g.
  • The folder name must be the group name. Example: To read the file blog_g/index.html you must have the group blog_g.
  • Developers can read/write.
  • Users can't read/write.
User Folder:
  • Users can have their own folder.
  • The folder name must be the username. Example: To read the file john@example.com/index.html you must be the user john@example.com.
  • Developers can read/write.
  • Users can't read/write.

doT.js

Many of our webcomponents use doT.js for record templates (among other things). For general information about doT.js go to http://olado.github.io/doT/

< and >

Sometimes you have a doT.js if like so:

{{? i < len }}
    // do stuff
{{?}}

But when the javscript gets to it, it looks like this:

{{? i &lt; len }}
    // do stuff
{{?}}

So we wrote the following functions:

gt(x,y):  x >  y
gte(x,y): x >= y
lt(x,y):  x <  y
lte(x,y): x <= y
Record templates

To address a column use row.<column>:

{{! row.test1 }}
 OR 
{{= row.test1 }}
